channel.title: Beer Advent Calendar 2005 on Ian Nelson
channel.description: Recent content in Beer Advent Calendar 2005 on Ian Nelson

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Twenty-Four
item.description: Hertog Jan Doppio Double is the only one of my twenty-four Advent beers to come in a stone cork-stoppered bottle that weighs more than the drink contained within! At 7.3% ABV, itâ€™s also the second-strongest drink in my selection, and hence has a real kick to it.That said, it also has a gorgeous malty aroma, and strong aftertaste which beer lovers will appreciate.So whilst itâ€™s not quite my personal favourite of the twenty-four beers Iâ€™ve had the pleasure of sampling this yuletide, itâ€™s certainly an appropriately worthy and warming drink on which to finish.
item.content:encoded:
Hertog Jan Doppio Double is the only one of my twenty-four Advent beers to come in a stone cork-stoppered bottle that weighs more than the drink contained within! At 7.3% ABV, itâ€™s also the second-strongest drink in my selection, and hence has a real kick to it.That said, it also has a gorgeous malty aroma, and strong aftertaste which beer lovers will appreciate.So whilst itâ€™s not quite my personal favourite of the twenty-four beers Iâ€™ve had the pleasure of sampling this yuletide, itâ€™s certainly an appropriately worthy and warming drink on which to finish.

Iâ€™ve been asked to summarise my findings on these beers at the end of the season, and was considering publishing a spreadsheet noting my opinions in various categories (colour, aroma, aftertaste, strength, packaging, cute namesâ€¦), but having consumed so many fine ales this month, it was beyond me to come up with such a complicated scoring system.Instead, Iâ€™ve made an effort to merely triage the beers according to my overall opinion and likelihood of repurchase â€“ those with three stars will be on our shopping list in future, whilst those with one star will be avoided like the plague.

Three-star beers:

Bitter & Twisted
Festive Filly
Fraoch
Hertog Jan
Nightmare
Riggwelter
Schiehallion
Whirlygig

Two-star beers:

Delirium Nocturnum
Jingle Knockers
Rolling Hitch
Rosey Nosey
Leffe Blonde
Nessieâ€™s Monster Mash
Ruby Red
Smugglerâ€™s Ale
Youngâ€™s Christmas Pudding Ale

One-star beers:

Crazy Edâ€™s Cave Creek Chili Beer
Honkerâ€™s Ale
Kronenbourg Blanc
Mars Magic
Morocco Ale
Rudolphâ€™s Revenge
Teignworthy Christmas Cracker

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Twenty-Three
item.description: The penultimate beer on my 2005 advent calendar was Ruby Red from the St. Peterâ€™s Brewery in Suffolk. Iâ€™d been looking forward to this 4.3% ABV red ale, which, like all of the beers from St. Peterâ€™s, comes in a distinctive flask-shaped oval bottle, so I was somewhat disappointed by the intense bitterness of the first few mouthfuls. However, I think this was mostly due to the effects of the Mexican dinner laced with Encona sauces that Iâ€™d scoffed a few minutes previously. Further into the bottle, the â€œsubtle malt undertones and spicy aromaâ€ became more apparent, and overall I really enjoyed this beer â€“ Iâ€™ll definitely be trying some of the others from the range.
item.content:encoded: The penultimate beer on my 2005 advent calendar was Ruby Red from the St. Peterâ€™s Brewery in Suffolk. Iâ€™d been looking forward to this 4.3% ABV red ale, which, like all of the beers from St. Peterâ€™s, comes in a distinctive flask-shaped oval bottle, so I was somewhat disappointed by the intense bitterness of the first few mouthfuls. However, I think this was mostly due to the effects of the Mexican dinner laced with Encona sauces that Iâ€™d scoffed a few minutes previously. Further into the bottle, the â€œsubtle malt undertones and spicy aromaâ€ became more apparent, and overall I really enjoyed this beer â€“ Iâ€™ll definitely be trying some of the others from the range.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Twenty-Two
item.description: Fraoch is a 5% ABV Scottish beer that brings back many happy memories of late nights spent in the bar at the Clachaig Inn. â€œFraochâ€ is the Gaelic for heather, so take a guess what this beer is made from? Â If youâ€™ve never tried it, that might sound a bit weird, but believe me that this is a great beer with â€œa floral, peaty aroma, full malt body, spicy herbal flavour and a dry wine like finishâ€. What more could you ask for? Â Slainte!
item.content:encoded: Fraoch is a 5% ABV Scottish beer that brings back many happy memories of late nights spent in the bar at the Clachaig Inn. â€œFraochâ€ is the Gaelic for heather, so take a guess what this beer is made from? Â If youâ€™ve never tried it, that might sound a bit weird, but believe me that this is a great beer with â€œa floral, peaty aroma, full malt body, spicy herbal flavour and a dry wine like finishâ€. What more could you ask for? Â Slainte!

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Twenty-One
item.description:
â€œJingle Knockersâ€ isnâ€™t exactly a phrase that inspires confidence, but this 5.5% ABV from Skinnerâ€™s Brewery in Cornwall is really good, definitely on a par with the stuff Iâ€™ve tried from Hambleton Ales and the Harviestoun Brewery. Smooth and strong, with subtle hints of Christmas pud â€“ mmmmâ€¦

Oh, and if youâ€™re still confused by that name, the label handily explains all:

â€œKnown as the Tin Mine Fairies, the Cornish Knockers used to guide the miners to the rich veins of ore by knocking. With the demise of mining over the years, many knockers have ;returned to grassâ€™ where, in disguise, they help with the brewing of their ales.â€
item.content:encoded:
â€œJingle Knockersâ€ isnâ€™t exactly a phrase that inspires confidence, but this 5.5% ABV from Skinnerâ€™s Brewery in Cornwall is really good, definitely on a par with the stuff Iâ€™ve tried from Hambleton Ales and the Harviestoun Brewery. Smooth and strong, with subtle hints of Christmas pud â€“ mmmmâ€¦

Oh, and if youâ€™re still confused by that name, the label handily explains all:

â€œKnown as the Tin Mine Fairies, the Cornish Knockers used to guide the miners to the rich veins of ore by knocking. With the demise of mining over the years, many knockers have ;returned to grassâ€™ where, in disguise, they help with the brewing of their ales.â€

So there you go! Â Gosh, isnâ€™t drinking beer every day educational?

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Twenty
item.description: Now, donâ€™t get me wrong, there are many great things that have originated from America â€“ not least of all my good lady wife â€“ but Iâ€™ve always thought that â€œAmerican Beerâ€ is something of an anachronism! Â Letâ€™s face it, most beers from across the Altlantic are sorely lacking in flavour, body, bitterness, or, well, anything remotely beerlike. So, whilst on my search for twenty-four bottled beers for this advent calendar, I was intrigued to find Honkerâ€™s Ale from the Goose Island Beer Company in Chicago which describes itself as â€œa smooth, drinkable English bitter for those drinkers who want more from their beerâ€. Well, letâ€™s hope theyâ€™re not looking for too much more, as it only comes in a 355ml bottle. It tastes OK when compared to the likes of Budweiser and Samuel Adams, but itâ€™s not exactly bold or challenging, and the whole experience was over far too quickly. Not exactly one to savour on a cold winterâ€™s night in Yorkshire, but I can imagine these going down quite well in the sports stadia of Iliinois.
item.content:encoded: Now, donâ€™t get me wrong, there are many great things that have originated from America â€“ not least of all my good lady wife â€“ but Iâ€™ve always thought that â€œAmerican Beerâ€ is something of an anachronism! Â Letâ€™s face it, most beers from across the Altlantic are sorely lacking in flavour, body, bitterness, or, well, anything remotely beerlike. So, whilst on my search for twenty-four bottled beers for this advent calendar, I was intrigued to find Honkerâ€™s Ale from the Goose Island Beer Company in Chicago which describes itself as â€œa smooth, drinkable English bitter for those drinkers who want more from their beerâ€. Well, letâ€™s hope theyâ€™re not looking for too much more, as it only comes in a 355ml bottle. It tastes OK when compared to the likes of Budweiser and Samuel Adams, but itâ€™s not exactly bold or challenging, and the whole experience was over far too quickly. Not exactly one to savour on a cold winterâ€™s night in Yorkshire, but I can imagine these going down quite well in the sports stadia of Iliinois.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Nineteen
item.description:
Smugglerâ€™s Ale is another bottled beer which found its way into my calendar via an Asda beer competition. Itâ€™s 5% ABV, with hints of treacle, and is really rather enjoyable.

And to paraphrase Forrest Gump, thatâ€™s all I have to say about that. Back to my beer and a DVD of Family Guy.
item.content:encoded:
Smugglerâ€™s Ale is another bottled beer which found its way into my calendar via an Asda beer competition. Itâ€™s 5% ABV, with hints of treacle, and is really rather enjoyable.

And to paraphrase Forrest Gump, thatâ€™s all I have to say about that. Back to my beer and a DVD of Family Guy.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Eighteen
item.description:
Thereâ€™s something a wee bit disappointing about picking up a bottle labelled â€œMOROCCO ALEâ€ and finding that it is, in fact, from nowhere more distant than Harrogate â€“ the Daleside Brewery to be precise. According to the label:

â€œThe recipe for Morocco Ale is believed to date from Elizabethan times. Colonel John Grahme of Levens was a courtier to James II and the name â€˜Moroccoâ€™ may have been associated with the dark Moors who came to the court when Catherine of Braganza married Charles II and brought Tangiers as part of her dowry.â€
item.content:encoded:
Thereâ€™s something a wee bit disappointing about picking up a bottle labelled â€œMOROCCO ALEâ€ and finding that it is, in fact, from nowhere more distant than Harrogate â€“ the Daleside Brewery to be precise. According to the label:

â€œThe recipe for Morocco Ale is believed to date from Elizabethan times. Colonel John Grahme of Levens was a courtier to James II and the name â€˜Moroccoâ€™ may have been associated with the dark Moors who came to the court when Catherine of Braganza married Charles II and brought Tangiers as part of her dowry.â€

Right. Whatever. Apparently this 5.5% beer is brewed to an ancient secret recipe, so itâ€™s curious that it tastes so strongly of rosemary. I mean, not just a little hint of the stuff, this really could conceivably be nothing more than fermented rosemary, the taste is so overwhelming. Which is certainly different, but Iâ€™m not sure itâ€™s really my thing.

Six beers to go â€“ wonder what tomorrow will bring?

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Days Sixteen And Seventeen
item.description:
Friday night saw me out celebrating in Halifax at our departmental Christmas meal (FWIW, I drank a few pints of Santaâ€™s Little Helper from the Caledonian brewery). As a result, I didnâ€™t get chance to enjoy my advent beer, and have been playing catch-up with a couple of randomly-selected bottles tonight.

Firstly, the sixteenth beer to be selected from the vase of fate was Delirium Nocturnum, a 9.0% ABV dark ale from the Huyghe-Melle brewery in Belgium which comes in silver glittery 330ml bottles featuring pictures of pink elephants. I was somewhat apprehensive, but needlessly so, as this is a surprisingly well-balanced and hoppy triply-fermented ale â€“ not a novelty drink at all (despite the packaging being somewhat reminiscent of a Pizza Express salad dressing bottle).
item.content:encoded:
Friday night saw me out celebrating in Halifax at our departmental Christmas meal (FWIW, I drank a few pints of Santaâ€™s Little Helper from the Caledonian brewery). As a result, I didnâ€™t get chance to enjoy my advent beer, and have been playing catch-up with a couple of randomly-selected bottles tonight.

Firstly, the sixteenth beer to be selected from the vase of fate was Delirium Nocturnum, a 9.0% ABV dark ale from the Huyghe-Melle brewery in Belgium which comes in silver glittery 330ml bottles featuring pictures of pink elephants. I was somewhat apprehensive, but needlessly so, as this is a surprisingly well-balanced and hoppy triply-fermented ale â€“ not a novelty drink at all (despite the packaging being somewhat reminiscent of a Pizza Express salad dressing bottle).

Secondly, todayâ€™s drink was Rolling Hitch, a 5.2% ABV India pale ale from the Darwin Brewery in Sunderland. This was specially created for the purposes of entering (and winning) a competition to supply all Asda stores. Itâ€™s fruity, sharp, bitter and hoppy â€“ very enjoyable. Oh, and in case you were wondering,a quick Googling reveals that a Rolling Hitch is a seafaring knot â€“ â€œif a jib sheet jams in a winch, you can attach a rolling hitch to take the pressure off the line as you undo the jamâ€ â€“ so now you know.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Days Thirteen, Fourteen and Fifteen!
item.description:
Gadzooks! Â Who would have thought that it would be so difficult to find a few minutes each day to transcribe a few words about a bottle of beer? Â But it is â€“ especially as we enter the party season and my evenings are filled with festivities.

The good news is, I have three excellent beers to report on; the first two of which are from breweries that Iâ€™ve already â€œvisitedâ€ during this advent calendar.
item.content:encoded:
Gadzooks! Â Who would have thought that it would be so difficult to find a few minutes each day to transcribe a few words about a bottle of beer? Â But it is â€“ especially as we enter the party season and my evenings are filled with festivities.

The good news is, I have three excellent beers to report on; the first two of which are from breweries that Iâ€™ve already â€œvisitedâ€ during this advent calendar.

Tuesdayâ€™s beer was Bitter & Twisted, from the Harviestoun Brewery (c.f. Schiehallion on day three). At 4.2% ABV itâ€™s a little lighter than Schiehallion, but itâ€™s equally delicious â€“ very fresh, sharp and hoppy, it was voted Champion Bottled Ale 2004. Mmmmm.

Wednesday I came back closer to home for a second beer from the Hambleton Ales microbrewery in Thirsk â€“ this time it was Festive Filly (ABV 4.5%), which is presumably a seasonal ale, and damn nice it is too. Another good winter warming beer.

Finally, today I enjoyed Nessieâ€™s Monster Mash, a 4.4% â€œpremium beerâ€ from the Cairngorm Brewery Company. Very pleasant, plenty of flavour â€“ Iâ€™d be interested in trying the cask version of this for comparison.

So there we have it, a trio of mighty fine ales from northern Britain, any one of which Iâ€™d love to have for a second time. Aaah, this beer advent calendar was *such* a good ideaâ€¦

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Twelve
item.description: Halfway through my great beer advent calendar 2005, and tonight Iâ€™ve enjoyed the popular Leffe Blonde, a potent and delicious 6.6% ABV beer from Belgium. Iâ€™ve been meaning to try this reknowned tipple since I utterly failed to identify a snippet of the label in one of those irritating Excel-based quizzes that circulates on the interweb periodically. Anyway, I wasnâ€™t disappointed â€“ the small bottle size (33cl) being more than made up for by the strength and the flavour (quite almondy, I thought). Thereâ€™s a good detailed review by someone with more effective taste buds than I over at the excellent Oxford Bottled Beer Database.
item.content:encoded: Halfway through my great beer advent calendar 2005, and tonight Iâ€™ve enjoyed the popular Leffe Blonde, a potent and delicious 6.6% ABV beer from Belgium. Iâ€™ve been meaning to try this reknowned tipple since I utterly failed to identify a snippet of the label in one of those irritating Excel-based quizzes that circulates on the interweb periodically. Anyway, I wasnâ€™t disappointed â€“ the small bottle size (33cl) being more than made up for by the strength and the flavour (quite almondy, I thought). Thereâ€™s a good detailed review by someone with more effective taste buds than I over at the excellent Oxford Bottled Beer Database.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Eleven
item.description:
I just realised that I forgot to blog about yesterdayâ€™s advent beer. Sorry for keeping you all on tenterhooks like that!

To be honest I was a bit disappointed and couldnâ€™t think of anything interesting to say about Rudolphâ€™s Revenge, a 4.6% ABV bitter from Cropton Brewery. It was quite similar to the equally uninspiring Mars Magic from last Thursday.
item.content:encoded:
I just realised that I forgot to blog about yesterdayâ€™s advent beer. Sorry for keeping you all on tenterhooks like that!

To be honest I was a bit disappointed and couldnâ€™t think of anything interesting to say about Rudolphâ€™s Revenge, a 4.6% ABV bitter from Cropton Brewery. It was quite similar to the equally uninspiring Mars Magic from last Thursday.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Ten
item.description: Ah, I do enjoy beers by the Wychwood Brewery, who have a particularly good website (i.e. better than most of the brewery sites Iâ€™ve come across so far). Hobgoblin is an obvious favourite, easily available from any supermarket worth its salt. Today I sampled their Whirlygig ale, a 4.5% â€œfrenzy of hops and maltâ€, which really is delicious. Lots of flavour, lots of character â€“ very enjoyable indeed. This one goes into the â€œbuy againâ€ column. Jocelyn didnâ€™t get a look in, so I canâ€™t give you the female opinion, sorry.
item.content:encoded: Ah, I do enjoy beers by the Wychwood Brewery, who have a particularly good website (i.e. better than most of the brewery sites Iâ€™ve come across so far). Hobgoblin is an obvious favourite, easily available from any supermarket worth its salt. Today I sampled their Whirlygig ale, a 4.5% â€œfrenzy of hops and maltâ€, which really is delicious. Lots of flavour, lots of character â€“ very enjoyable indeed. This one goes into the â€œbuy againâ€ column. Jocelyn didnâ€™t get a look in, so I canâ€™t give you the female opinion, sorry.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Nine
item.description: Rosey Nosey by Batemanâ€™s Brewery has a deceptively cutesy name, but it turns out to be a really decent-quality ale with plenty of flavour and a pleasing warmth. If you have to buy one festive-themed beer this year, you could do much worse than this one.
item.content:encoded: Rosey Nosey by Batemanâ€™s Brewery has a deceptively cutesy name, but it turns out to be a really decent-quality ale with plenty of flavour and a pleasing warmth. If you have to buy one festive-themed beer this year, you could do much worse than this one.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Eight
item.description:
Another day, another beer.Itâ€™s a hard life.Mars Magic is a rather unexciting 4.6% ABV â€œPremium Aleâ€ (it says here) from the Wold Top Brewery.Noticeably lacking in anything resembling a head, it did however seem to improve as I progressed through the half-litre (funny how that happens).So, with my whistle well and truly whetted, Iâ€™m off down the pub.Cya!

Oh, I nearly forgot to record Joceâ€™s comments on the bitter.It went something like: â€œEurgh!â€
item.content:encoded:
Another day, another beer.Itâ€™s a hard life.Mars Magic is a rather unexciting 4.6% ABV â€œPremium Aleâ€ (it says here) from the Wold Top Brewery.Noticeably lacking in anything resembling a head, it did however seem to improve as I progressed through the half-litre (funny how that happens).So, with my whistle well and truly whetted, Iâ€™m off down the pub.Cya!

Oh, I nearly forgot to record Joceâ€™s comments on the bitter.It went something like: â€œEurgh!â€

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Seven
item.description: Wednesday nightâ€™s tipple was the rather strange 5% ABV Kronenbourg Blanc, from UK brewing giant Scottish & Newcastle. Described as a â€œrefreshing, fruity white beerâ€, this is in fact blatantly piss-coloured (which probably explains why it comes in an opaque bottle). I found this to be more reminiscent of a weak cider or some kind of bizarre citrus alcopop than anything deserving to have the word â€œbeerâ€ on the label. Still, try everything once except Morris Dancing and incest, as the saying goes.
item.content:encoded:
Wednesday nightâ€™s tipple was the rather strange 5% ABV Kronenbourg Blanc, from UK brewing giant Scottish & Newcastle. Described as a â€œrefreshing, fruity white beerâ€, this is in fact blatantly piss-coloured (which probably explains why it comes in an opaque bottle). I found this to be more reminiscent of a weak cider or some kind of bizarre citrus alcopop than anything deserving to have the word â€œbeerâ€ on the label. Still, try everything once except Morris Dancing and incest, as the saying goes.

Jocelyn says: â€œThis is a girly beer! Â I could drink this! Â This is fruity, itâ€™s not a beer at all!â€

Weird advertising, too â€“ would you buy a drink for this girl?

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Six
item.description: A return to form today, with the vase of fate serving up a helping of Riggwelter, the Black Sheep Breweryâ€™s delicious 4.7% strong Yorkshire ale.I could drink this till the cows come home.Or perhaps that should be the sheep, for (according to the bottle) the name Riggwelter comes from the Old Norse rygg meaning to overturn.â€œWhen a sheep is on its back and cannot get up without help, local dales dialect says itâ€™s rigged or riggwelted.â€
item.content:encoded:
A return to form today, with the vase of fate serving up a helping of Riggwelter, the Black Sheep Breweryâ€™s delicious 4.7% strong Yorkshire ale.I could drink this till the cows come home.Or perhaps that should be the sheep, for (according to the bottle) the name Riggwelter comes from the Old Norse rygg meaning to overturn.â€œWhen a sheep is on its back and cannot get up without help, local dales dialect says itâ€™s rigged or riggwelted.â€

Jocelyn says: â€œThatâ€™s cheating, youâ€™ve had that one before, youâ€™re supposed to be trying something new.Iâ€™m not interestedâ€.

She speaks the truth, this isnâ€™t exactly my first Riggwelter.In fact Iâ€™ve taken Joce to visit the brewery in Masham before ğŸ™‚

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Five
item.description:
Todayâ€™s festive ale is the Teignworthy Christmas Cracker, a strong (6% ABV) dark and warming malty bottle conditioned ale from deepest Devon.

Um, itâ€™s OK, certainly tastes weighty and, well, worthy, but it isnâ€™t really to my taste â€“ it has a very strong aftertaste yet is lacking in any interesting fruity flavours.There are plenty of other things Iâ€™d rather drink before picking this.

Jocelyn says: â€œDamn, Iâ€™ve dripped it on my top, Iâ€™ll have to wash this now.â€
item.content:encoded:
Todayâ€™s festive ale is the Teignworthy Christmas Cracker, a strong (6% ABV) dark and warming malty bottle conditioned ale from deepest Devon.

Um, itâ€™s OK, certainly tastes weighty and, well, worthy, but it isnâ€™t really to my taste â€“ it has a very strong aftertaste yet is lacking in any interesting fruity flavours.There are plenty of other things Iâ€™d rather drink before picking this.

Jocelyn says: â€œDamn, Iâ€™ve dripped it on my top, Iâ€™ll have to wash this now.â€

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Four
item.description: Another superb ale tonight, and this one is close to home. NightmareÂ by the Hambleton Ales microbrewery in Thirsk is an extremely creamy, fruity, and flavoursome stoutâ€”not as bitter as you might expect from its appearance. Very tastyâ€”Iâ€™ll definitely be buying this again.
item.content:encoded: Another superb ale tonight, and this one is close to home. NightmareÂ by the Hambleton Ales microbrewery in Thirsk is an extremely creamy, fruity, and flavoursome stoutâ€”not as bitter as you might expect from its appearance. Very tastyâ€”Iâ€™ll definitely be buying this again.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Three
item.description:
Third Time Lucky!

After two days of novelty nonsense, the vase of fate finally served up a half-litre of Harviestoun Breweryâ€™s 4.8% masterpiece,Â Schiehallion, named after my all-time favourite Munro.

Hereâ€™s an interesting fact for you: the mass of the Earth was first measured in 1774 when the Astronomer Royal, one Nevil Maskelyne, spent four months mucking about on Schiehallion with pendulums. By observing how the mountainâ€™s bulk caused the pendulums (pendula?) to swing away from the vertical, he was able to estimate the mountainâ€™s mass and extrapolate from this to calculate our planetâ€™s mass at 5,000 million million tonnesâ€”which is a pretty reasonable estimate, if you ask me. Based on that work, it then became possible to determine the mass of all the other planets, their moons, and even the Sun itself. All of which rather puts my own summerâ€™s evening stroll up Schiehallion in 1998 into perspective, enjoyable though it was.
item.content:encoded:
Third Time Lucky!

After two days of novelty nonsense, the vase of fate finally served up a half-litre of Harviestoun Breweryâ€™s 4.8% masterpiece,Â Schiehallion, named after my all-time favourite Munro.

Hereâ€™s an interesting fact for you: the mass of the Earth was first measured in 1774 when the Astronomer Royal, one Nevil Maskelyne, spent four months mucking about on Schiehallion with pendulums. By observing how the mountainâ€™s bulk caused the pendulums (pendula?) to swing away from the vertical, he was able to estimate the mountainâ€™s mass and extrapolate from this to calculate our planetâ€™s mass at 5,000 million million tonnesâ€”which is a pretty reasonable estimate, if you ask me. Based on that work, it then became possible to determine the mass of all the other planets, their moons, and even the Sun itself. All of which rather puts my own summerâ€™s evening stroll up Schiehallion in 1998 into perspective, enjoyable though it was.

Oh, and the beerâ€™s great too, by the way. Cask-conditioned, Bohemian style, lovely and refreshing, with a taste evocative of Scottish moorland and heather. Itâ€™s even won gold medals at CAMRAâ€™s Great British Beer Festival.

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day Two
item.description:
Well, this eveningâ€™s advent beer couldnâ€™t be more different from yesterdayâ€™s. I had the dubious pleasure of sampling Crazy Edâ€™s Cave Creek Chili Beer, all the way from Arizona.

Be warned: the website dates from 1999, and boy, does it showâ€”weâ€™re talking Comic Sans in a scrolling <marquee> tag, framesets that have a tendency to get confused (try clicking the â€œhomeâ€ link), and a 53-kilopixel JPEG weighing in at an astonishing 232 KB (why?!). Seeing those â€œNetscape Now!â€ animated GIFs makes me all nostalgic for the twentieth centuryâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
Well, this eveningâ€™s advent beer couldnâ€™t be more different from yesterdayâ€™s. I had the dubious pleasure of sampling Crazy Edâ€™s Cave Creek Chili Beer, all the way from Arizona.

Be warned: the website dates from 1999, and boy, does it showâ€”weâ€™re talking Comic Sans in a scrolling <marquee> tag, framesets that have a tendency to get confused (try clicking the â€œhomeâ€ link), and a 53-kilopixel JPEG weighing in at an astonishing 232 KB (why?!). Seeing those â€œNetscape Now!â€ animated GIFs makes me all nostalgic for the twentieth centuryâ€¦

Ahem. But enough about the siteâ€”what about the beer? Well, it was a lucky choice for this evening, as Joce had made Mexican for dinner. It was certainly spicy (with a whole chili pod in the bottle), but to be honest, I would have preferred a nice, refreshing Corona or Sol. As with yesterdayâ€™s offering, this was a fun novelty drink as a one-off, but not something I could happily sup all evening.

Joce says: â€œOh! Ow! Oh my God! Oh, man! That is the hottest thing Iâ€™ve ever tasted! My throat is on fire!â€

item.title: Beer Advent Calendar â€“ Day One
item.description:
This is surely one of the best ideas Iâ€™ve ever had! Iâ€™ve followed through with my plan to buy twenty-four beers from around the world to count down the days until Christmas. Their names are all written on slips of folded paper in a small vase (nobody actually draws things out of a hat anymore, do they?).

Today Iâ€™m enjoyingÂ Youngâ€™s Christmas Pudding Ale, which is 5.5% ABV according to the bottle but only 5.0% according to the websiteâ€”donâ€™t believe everything you read on the web, eh?
item.content:encoded:
This is surely one of the best ideas Iâ€™ve ever had! Iâ€™ve followed through with my plan to buy twenty-four beers from around the world to count down the days until Christmas. Their names are all written on slips of folded paper in a small vase (nobody actually draws things out of a hat anymore, do they?).

Today Iâ€™m enjoyingÂ Youngâ€™s Christmas Pudding Ale, which is 5.5% ABV according to the bottle but only 5.0% according to the websiteâ€”donâ€™t believe everything you read on the web, eh?

The tasting notes say:

With its warming, dark ruby character and the splendid luscious flavour of dried fruit, Youngâ€™s Christmas Pudding Ale is an inspirational addition to any Christmas feast or fireside gathering.

I say itâ€™s tastyâ€”pleasant as a singleton but probably a bit too fruity for a prolonged sesh. It really does smell like figgy pudding, too!

If this were a track on my iPod, Iâ€™d probably give it four stars.

Jocelyn says: â€œHuh? I canâ€™t taste any fruit. Nope, tastes like beer to me. Iâ€™d prefer a Guinness.â€

I wonder what tomorrow will bringâ€¦
